Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Assessing the Reliability of Levees in Changing Geologic Conditions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is to investigate methods of assessing the risk of levee failure as a result of variable geologic conditions along the length of the levee. As levees are loaded during floods, water will begin to seep through both the levee and through the levee foundation. At low flow velocities the water will pass through the soil matrix without significantly affecting it. However, as the river water rises, the amount of seepage increases and the velocity of the seeping water and/or the pressure of the seeping water increases in response. This increases the potential for erosion of soil from within the levee or its foundation, a phenomenon known as internal erosion. If allowed to continue, internal erosion can lead to instability and eventual failure of the levee. Current levee evaluation methods assume relatively uniform subsurface conditions for assessing seepage behavior. However, buried geologic structures in the near-surface soils left behind by prehistoric creek or river channels often have a huge effect on the seepage behavior in the levee foundation, often to the point where these structures control the reliability of the levee with respect to internal erosion. This award supports research to provide needed knowledge for the development of a method for assessing the underseepage risk to levee reaches that have variable geologic features in their foundation. The new assessment procedures takes into account the three-dimensional aspects of the seepage flow into these features and assesses the probability of developing seepage conditions where internal erosion is likely to initiate. By mapping where these features occur along a long levee reach and evaluating the risk each of these features poses to the levee, we can evaluate the reliability of the entire levee reach by combining the risks of the various geologic features located along their alignment. The results of this research will assist engineers in assessing where levees present unacceptable risk to the land they protect. Because there are thousands of miles of levees in the United States needing evaluation and mitigation for underseepage, this methodology has the potential to greatly improve the efficiency at which available funds are spent to increase the reliability of this critical aspect of our nation's infrastructure.

This project transforms the analysis strategy and methodology for assessing risk to linear geotechnical projects constructed over varied geologic conditions. The project is formulated specifically for levees but the methods developed will also be applicable to other linear structures or projects. The analysis framework consists of robust reliability analyses (response surface Monte Carlo analyses) that are applied to individual geomorphic features to estimate the probability of key hydraulic parameters reaching levels where the initiation of internal erosion is likely. These probabilities will then be combined with the likelihood of other steps in the internal erosion failure process occurring to obtain the probability of failure due to each geomorphic feature along the project alignment. The resulting probabilities will then be statistically combined to obtain the total risk to the project due to the failure mechanisms considered. This methodology provides a robust means for assessing the total risk to linear structures in a way that accounts for length effects and the geologic hazards located along their alignment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Levees are long, linear structures built to protect land from flooding rivers and rising bodies of water. Along rivers levee foundations are characterized by variable foundation conditions deposited as the river meandered across the flood plain, leaving coarse-grained soil in the main channel and fine-grained soils when the river exited the channel into the flood plain during flooding (overbank deposits). The resulting levee foundation is often characterized in a simplified manner as having a near-surface layer of fine-grained overbank deposited (often referred to as the "blanket" layer) underlain by a "foundation" layer of coarse-grained soils (sands and gravels). However, this foundation stratigraphy is often interspersed with geomorphic features laid down by the changing river environment, which give the levee foundation a much more complex character that is difficult to analyze.

As water rises on the river side of the levee it imposes a differential hydraulic head across the levee causing water to seep through the foundation soils, a phenomenon often referred to as underseepage. When the rate of underseepage is high, soil particles on the land side of the levee can be dislodged by the hydraulic forces of the seeping water. As additional soil particles are removed, an underground channel or "pipe" is formed leading back from the ground surface and toward the source of the seepage. If allowed to progress, the pipe can extend back to the source of the water (river) and gross enlargement of the pipe can lead to levee failure. This phenomenon is known as backward erosion piping (BEP) and is the cause of a large percentage of levee failures along meandering river systems in teh USA such as the Mississippi River and Sacramento River.

Present methods for assessing the potential for BEP initiation due to underseepage consist of developing a simplified, two-dimensional levee profile and analyzing the seepage regime using either simplified equations (the US Army Corps of Engineers "blanket theory" equations) or numerical modeling such as finite-element analysis using computer codes. These analyses are often performed deterministically, meaning they use a single, best-estimate value for all the input parameters that describe teh soil properties and the geometry of the levee profile. In some cases, simplified probabilistic analyses have been performed that allow for inclusion of uncertainty in the input parameters, which result in a probability of exceeding a triggering value condition that can lead to BEP initiation.

The methods described above have several shortcomings that have been addressed by the research in this project. First, the methods are two-dimensional and underseepage is largely a three-dimensional phenomenon, especially when geomorphic features are included in the analysis. Second, they consider a simplified profile that does not account for the inclusion of geomorphic features which are considered the main source of underseepage and BEP hazards, Finally, they don't account for the uncertainty in the input parameters controlling the phenomenon or, it they do, (in the case of the simplified probabilistic analysis) they must oversimplify the geometry of the foundation.

This study has developed  a new method for assessing BEP initiation potential that allows for incorporation of geomorphic features in a three-dimensional model and accounts for the variability of the input parameters. The Response Surface-Monte Carlo (RSMC) simulation method uses three-dimensional finite-element analyses to develop a series of equations that define the relationship between essential soil and geometric input parameters and the probability of initiation of BEP erosion due to attainment  of critical hydraulic conditions (i.e. uplift pressures or hydraulic exit gradients) for a given flood condition. This series of equations is referred to as the "Response Surface". The project has developed response surfaces for several types of geomorphic features that are commonly encountered along levee encountered along levee alignments including: point bars, abandoned channels, crevasse splays, and infilled oxbows. These response surfaces can be used to assess the probability of exceeding critical values for assessing the initiation of BEP due to individual geomorphic features along a levee alignment. These response surfaces can be used to assess the probability of exceeding critical values for assessing the initiation of BEP due to individual geomorphic features along a levee alignment by inputting the range and distribution of uncertainty for each parameter of each feature. Then, by adding the probability of failure for all features along a levee alignment, the total probability of failure for the levee reach can be assessed.

The study also analyzed the effects of levee curvature on the seepage regime that is controlled by geomorphic features. Levee curvature can increase hydraulic pressures on the landside of the levee due to converging seepage pathways. A simplified means for assessing these curvature effects was developed that uses a chart solution to determine a multiplier for increasing the critical values controlling BEP initiation.
